title: Surrogate-assisted global sensitivity analysis of a hybrid-dimensional Stokes--Brinkman--Darcy model
summary: Development of new multiscale mathematical models often entails considerable complexity and multiple undetermined parameters, typically arising from closure relations. To enable reliable simulations, one must quantify how uncertain physical parameters influence model predictions. We propose surrogate-assisted global sensitivity analysis that combines computational efficiency with a rigorous assessment of parameter influence. In this work, we analyze the recently proposed hybrid-dimensional Stokes--Brinkman--Darcy model, which describes fluid flows in coupled free-flow and porous-medium systems with arbitrary flow directions at the fluid--porous interface. The model results from vertical averaging and contains several unknown parameters. We perform surrogate-assisted global sensitivity analysis using Sobol' indices to investigate the sensitivity of the model to variations of physical parameters for two test cases: filtration and splitting flows. However, constructing surrogates for higher-dimensional random fields requires either many training runs or sophisticated sampling strategies. To address this, we compare polynomial chaos surrogates, including sparse and multi-resolution representations, for their efficiency in global sensitivity analysis, using a predefined Sobol' sequence of training samples. Across the tested cases, multi-resolution approach delivers the most accurate estimation of Sobol' indices.

AI.tldr: Surrogate-assisted global sensitivity analysis for hybrid-dimensional Stokes-Brinkman-Darcy model using polynomial chaos surrogates to quantify parameter influence on coupled free-flow/porous-medium systems.
AI.motivation: Multiscale mathematical models often have complex closure relations with multiple undetermined parameters, requiring quantification of how uncertain physical parameters influence model predictions for reliable simulations.
AI.method: Proposed surrogate-assisted global sensitivity analysis combining computational efficiency with rigorous parameter influence assessment. Used Sobol' indices to analyze hybrid-dimensional Stokes-Brinkman-Darcy model. Compared polynomial chaos surrogates (sparse and multi-resolution representations) using predefined Sobol' sequence training samples.
AI.result: Multi-resolution approach delivered the most accurate estimation of Sobol' indices across tested cases (filtration and splitting flows). Surrogate-assisted approach enables efficient sensitivity analysis for higher-dimensional random fields.
AI.conclusion: Surrogate-assisted global sensitivity analysis with multi-resolution polynomial chaos surrogates provides efficient and accurate parameter influence assessment for complex multiscale models with uncertain physical parameters.

title: Convergence Analysis of a Linear, Unconditionally Energy-Stable SAV Finite Element Method for the Cahn-Hilliard Equation
summary: This paper proposes a finite element scheme, based on the Scalar Auxiliary Variable (SAV) approach, for the Cahn-Hilliard equation--a model that possesses significant physical relevance and a rich mathematical structure. A convergence analysis of the fully discrete scheme is conducted under suitable regularity assumptions, confirming optimal-order convergence in both time and space for the phase variable, chemical potential, and auxiliary variable in the H1-norm. Furthermore, the scheme is proven to be unconditionally energy stable. Finally, a numerical example is presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the method and to confirm the theoretical convergence rates.

AI.tldr: A finite element scheme using Scalar Auxiliary Variable (SAV) approach for the Cahn-Hilliard equation, with proven unconditional energy stability and optimal-order convergence.
AI.motivation: The Cahn-Hilliard equation has significant physical relevance and rich mathematical structure, but developing stable and convergent numerical schemes for it is challenging. The authors aim to create a finite element scheme that maintains both unconditional energy stability and optimal convergence rates.
AI.method: Proposes a finite element scheme based on the Scalar Auxiliary Variable (SAV) approach for the Cahn-Hilliard equation. The method involves fully discrete formulation with convergence analysis under suitable regularity assumptions.
AI.result: The scheme achieves optimal-order convergence in both time and space for the phase variable, chemical potential, and auxiliary variable in the H1-norm. It is proven to be unconditionally energy stable. Numerical examples confirm the theoretical convergence rates and demonstrate method effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: The proposed SAV-based finite element scheme successfully solves the Cahn-Hilliard equation with unconditional energy stability and optimal convergence rates, making it an effective numerical method for this physically important model.

title: Adaptive isogeometric analysis of high-order phase-field fracture based on THB-splines
summary: In recent decades, the study of fracture propagation in solids has increasingly relied on phase-field models. Several recent contributions have highlighted the potential of this approach in both static and dynamic frameworks. However, a major limitation remains the high computational cost. Two main strategies have been identified to mitigate this issue: the use of locally refined meshes and the adoption of higher-order models. In this work, leveraging Truncated Hierarchical B-splines (THB-splines), we introduce adaptive simulations of higher-order phase-field formulations (AT1 and AT2), focusing primarily on two-dimensional fracture problems.

AI.tldr: Adaptive higher-order phase-field fracture modeling using THB-splines for computational efficiency
AI.motivation: Phase-field models for fracture propagation are computationally expensive, requiring strategies like local mesh refinement and higher-order formulations to reduce computational costs.
AI.method: Introduce adaptive simulations using Truncated Hierarchical B-splines (THB-splines) for higher-order phase-field formulations (AT1 and AT2), focusing on 2D fracture problems.
AI.result: Not specified in the abstract - this appears to be a methodology paper introducing the approach rather than reporting specific numerical results.
AI.conclusion: The paper presents an adaptive higher-order phase-field fracture modeling framework using THB-splines to address computational efficiency challenges in fracture propagation simulations.

title: A dual lumping procedure for static condensation in mixed NURBS-based isogeometric elements with optimal convergence rates for arbitrary open knot vectors
comment: 52 pages, 18 figures, 2 tables, Preprint submitted to Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering
summary: Locking is a common effect in finite element and isogeometric analysis. In the case of plates, transverse shear locking is most prominent, for shells several other types of locking exist. A common cure are mixed methods that introduce additional fields of unknowns into the variational formulation. These fields reduce constraints and thus alleviate locking significantly. As a drawback, the discretized additional fields increase computational costs significantly. These fields are often eliminated by static condensation, which requires the inverse of a part of the stiffness matrix. In Lagrange-based finite elements, this inverse is computed on element level, due to a discontinuous interpolation of additional fields. Since isogeometric analysis features higher continuity, static condensation must be performed on patch level, which requires a costly matrix inversion on that level. In this contribution, the virtual shear parameters of a mixed isogeometric plate formulation are interpolated by enhanced approximate dual basis functions. This allows to conduct row-sum lumping of the relevant matrix part at a minimal loss of accuracy, since this part becomes diagonal dominant. For a properly chosen integration space, this lumped matrix becomes the identity matrix. Thus, the proposed condensation procedure does not require an inversion anymore. The crucial and novel point is the proposed treatment of knot vectors with limited internal continuity. With the help of several single- and multi-patch examples, both with full and with limited internal continuity, we show that the proposed procedure obtains optimal error convergence rates in all cases, while without these alterations, convergence rates are significantly deteriorated.

AI.tldr: Proposes enhanced dual basis functions for mixed isogeometric plate analysis to enable row-sum lumping, eliminating costly matrix inversion in static condensation while maintaining optimal convergence rates.
AI.motivation: Mixed methods in isogeometric analysis require static condensation that involves costly matrix inversion on patch level due to higher continuity, unlike Lagrange elements where it's done on element level.
AI.method: Interpolate virtual shear parameters using enhanced approximate dual basis functions, enabling row-sum lumping of relevant matrix part which becomes diagonal dominant. For proper integration space, lumped matrix becomes identity matrix, eliminating inversion.
AI.result: The proposed procedure obtains optimal error convergence rates in single- and multi-patch examples with both full and limited internal continuity, while standard methods show significantly deteriorated convergence.
AI.conclusion: Enhanced dual basis functions enable efficient static condensation without matrix inversion in mixed isogeometric plate formulations, maintaining accuracy while reducing computational costs.

title: Kolmogorov Scaling for Total Energy and Cross Helicity in Magnetohydrodynamic Turbulence
summary: The problem of scaling in isotropic magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence has remained unresolved, with competing predictions of $k^{-5/3}$ (Kolmogorov) and $k^{-3/2}$ (Iroshnikov-Kraichnan) scalings. In this paper, we address this long-standing controversy using high-resolution numerical simulations on $8192^2$ and $1536^3$ grids. We show that the total energy and cross helicity spectra are closer to $k^{-5/3}$ than $k^{-3/2}$. The fluxes and structure functions of the total energy and cross helicity also demonstrate robust support for Kolmogorov scaling. The magnetic energy shows $k^{-5/3}$ spectrum, but the kinetic energy exhibits $k^{-3/2}$ spectrum; the latter spectrum is due to the energy transfers from the magnetic field to the velocity field.

AI.tldr: High-resolution MHD turbulence simulations resolve the scaling controversy, showing total energy follows Kolmogorov's k^{-5/3} scaling rather than Iroshnikov-Kraichnan's k^{-3/2} scaling.
AI.motivation: To resolve the long-standing controversy in isotropic MHD turbulence scaling between competing predictions of Kolmogorov (k^{-5/3}) and Iroshnikov-Kraichnan (k^{-3/2}) scalings.
AI.method: High-resolution numerical simulations on 8192² and 1536³ grids to analyze energy spectra, fluxes, and structure functions in isotropic MHD turbulence.
AI.result: Total energy and cross helicity spectra are closer to k^{-5/3} than k^{-3/2}; magnetic energy shows k^{-5/3} spectrum while kinetic energy exhibits k^{-3/2} spectrum due to energy transfers from magnetic to velocity fields.
AI.conclusion: The study provides robust support for Kolmogorov scaling in isotropic MHD turbulence, resolving the long-standing controversy through comprehensive high-resolution simulations.

title: Scattering map for the Vlasov--Poisson system with a repulsive harmonic potential
summary: We consider the Vlasov--Poisson system with a repulsive harmonic potential and prove the (modified) scattering of solutions, as well as the existence of wave operators, in any spatial dimension $d\geq 2$. The main novelty of this work is the construction of the wave operators and the introduction of the lens transform for the Vlasov--Poisson system. In addition, we provide a new and simpler proof that relaxes the assumptions on the initial data compared with those in Bigorgne, Velozo Ruiz, and Velozo Ruiz (2025) and Velozo Ruiz, and Velozo Ruiz (2024).

AI.tldr: Modified scattering and wave operators for Vlasov-Poisson system with repulsive harmonic potential in dimensions d≥2, using lens transform and simpler proof with relaxed assumptions.
AI.motivation: To study the long-time behavior of solutions to the Vlasov-Poisson system with repulsive harmonic potential, extending scattering theory to this setting and improving upon previous results.
AI.method: Introduces lens transform for Vlasov-Poisson system, constructs wave operators, and provides new simpler proof that relaxes initial data assumptions compared to previous works.
AI.result: Proves modified scattering of solutions and existence of wave operators for Vlasov-Poisson system with repulsive harmonic potential in any spatial dimension d≥2.
AI.conclusion: The paper establishes scattering theory for Vlasov-Poisson with harmonic potential, introduces novel lens transform technique, and provides improved results with less restrictive assumptions than previous works.

title: Using Neural Networks to Accelerate TALYS-2.0 Nuclear Reaction Simulations
summary: Recent efforts to improve the predictability of TALYS-2.0 calculated charged-particle residual product cross sections have focused on adjusting parameters related to the optical model potential and pre-equilibrium process. Although adjusted TALYS-2.0 outputs show marked improvements in agreement with experimental data over the default parameters, the procedure is generally time-consuming due to the need for sequential TALYS-2.0 calculations. Since the models and model parameters must be defined and constrained prior to adjustment, we show in this work that an artificial neural network can serve as a surrogate model to successfully predict TALYS-2.0 outputs within this domain of input parameters. No practical differences were observed in the trained model's performance between uniform random, Latin hypercube and Sobol sequence sampling for generating the training datasets. Once validated, trained neural network models were used to adjust TALYS-2.0 nuclear model parameters, where a multi-parameter fitting procedure was not only feasible but optimal for this process. The neural network approach is >1000x faster at generating residual product cross sections than using TALYS-2.0 directly, and a high-fidelity surrogate model could be implemented with about 1500 TALYS-2.0 files to achieve adjusted cross sections comparable to the previous publication.

AI.tldr: Using neural networks as surrogate models for TALYS-2.0 nuclear reaction calculations dramatically speeds up parameter adjustment for predicting charged-particle residual product cross sections.
AI.motivation: Traditional parameter adjustment in TALYS-2.0 for improving cross-section predictions is time-consuming due to sequential calculations. There's a need for faster methods to optimize optical model potential and pre-equilibrium parameters.
AI.method: Developed artificial neural network surrogate models trained on TALYS-2.0 outputs. Compared different sampling methods (uniform random, Latin hypercube, Sobol sequence) for training data generation. Used trained models for multi-parameter fitting of nuclear model parameters.
AI.result: Neural network approach is >1000x faster than direct TALYS-2.0 calculations. No practical differences observed between sampling methods. High-fidelity surrogate models achieved with ~1500 TALYS-2.0 files, producing adjusted cross sections comparable to previous publications.
AI.conclusion: Neural network surrogate models provide a highly efficient alternative to direct TALYS-2.0 calculations for parameter adjustment, enabling feasible multi-parameter fitting and dramatically reducing computational time while maintaining accuracy.

title: Kernel Methods for the Construction of Certified Lyapunov Functions via Approximate Koopman Eigenfunctions
summary: We present a kernel-based methodology for constructing Lyapunov functions for nonlinear dynamical systems using approximate Koopman eigenfunctions. Our approach decomposes principal Koopman eigenfunctions into linear and nonlinear components, where the linear part is obtained from the system's linearization and the nonlinear part is computed by solving a partial differential equation using symmetric kernel collocation in reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces (RKHS). The resulting Lyapunov function is constructed as a quadratic form in the approximate eigenfunctions. We establish error bounds relating the approximation quality to the fill distance of collocation points and provide a certification procedure using continuous piecewise affine (CPA) methods. Numerical experiments on benchmark systems, including a polynomial system and the Duffing oscillator, demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach.

AI.tldr: Kernel-based method for constructing Lyapunov functions using approximate Koopman eigenfunctions with error bounds and certification.
AI.motivation: Need systematic methods to construct Lyapunov functions for nonlinear dynamical systems, which are crucial for stability analysis but often difficult to find analytically.
AI.method: Decompose Koopman eigenfunctions into linear (from system linearization) and nonlinear parts, solve PDE using symmetric kernel collocation in RKHS, construct Lyapunov function as quadratic form in approximate eigenfunctions.
AI.result: Established error bounds related to collocation point density, developed certification procedure using CPA methods, demonstrated effectiveness on polynomial systems and Duffing oscillator.
AI.conclusion: The kernel-based approach provides a systematic, certifiable method for constructing Lyapunov functions for nonlinear systems using Koopman operator theory with rigorous error guarantees.

title: Passive freeze-out of the Richtmyer-Meshkov instability
summary: The Richtmyer-Meshkov instability (RMI) poses a major challenge in inertial confinement fusion (ICF) due to its role in mixing and performance degradation. We report the first experimental observation of passive freeze-out of RMI in a low-pressure surrogate regime; an instability stagnation effect induced without modifying the driving pressure pulse or the target surface geometry. Using additively manufactured sub-surface voids in a sinusoidal target, we convert a single shock into a sequence of weaker shocks that suppress instability growth upstream of the surface by over 70%. High-speed X-ray imaging and hydrodynamic simulations suggest that this suppression arises primarily from temporal shaping, with lesser contributions from spatial curvature and shock weakening. Our results demonstrate a driver-independent pathway for controlling shock-driven hydrodynamic instabilities relevant to ICF and other high energy density systems.

AI.tldr: First experimental observation of passive freeze-out of Richtmyer-Meshkov instability using additively manufactured sub-surface voids to convert a single shock into weaker shocks, suppressing instability growth by over 70% without modifying driving pressure or target geometry.
AI.motivation: The Richtmyer-Meshkov instability (RMI) is a major challenge in inertial confinement fusion (ICF) as it causes mixing and performance degradation. There's a need for driver-independent methods to control these shock-driven hydrodynamic instabilities.
AI.method: Used additively manufactured sub-surface voids in a sinusoidal target to convert a single shock into a sequence of weaker shocks. Employed high-speed X-ray imaging and hydrodynamic simulations to analyze the suppression mechanism.
AI.result: Achieved over 70% suppression of instability growth upstream of the surface. Found that suppression arises primarily from temporal shaping of the shock sequence, with lesser contributions from spatial curvature and shock weakening.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrated a driver-independent pathway for controlling shock-driven hydrodynamic instabilities relevant to ICF and other high energy density systems through passive freeze-out of RMI using engineered sub-surface structures.

title: Yet another look at narrow escape through a tube
summary: The narrow escape problem concerns the time needed for a diffusing particle to exit a confining domain through a small hole in the boundary. While this problem is now well-understood, determining the escape time for a particle that must exit through a narrow tube has proven challenging. Indeed, relying on analogies with electrodynamics, parameter fits to simulations, and heuristics, a variety of conflicting estimates for this escape time have been offered over the last three decades, some of which are counterintuitive and arguably non-physical. In this paper, we combine matched asymptotic analysis and probabilistic methods to determine the exact asymptotics of the narrow escape time through a tube. We obtain a new escape time formula which reduces to the various prior estimates in certain special cases. If the diffusivity in the tube differs from the diffusivity in the rest of the domain, our results reveal the importance of the form of the multiplicative noise inherent to any diffusivity that varies in space. We discuss our results in the context of asymmetric cell division.

AI.tldr: The paper develops an exact asymptotic formula for the escape time of a diffusing particle through a narrow tube, resolving decades of conflicting estimates and revealing the importance of multiplicative noise when diffusivity varies spatially.
AI.motivation: For three decades, conflicting and sometimes non-physical estimates have been proposed for the escape time of a diffusing particle through a narrow tube, despite the narrow escape problem through a small hole being well-understood. The motivation is to resolve these inconsistencies and provide a rigorous solution.
AI.method: The authors combine matched asymptotic analysis and probabilistic methods to determine the exact asymptotics of the narrow escape time through a tube.
AI.result: They obtain a new escape time formula that reduces to prior estimates in special cases and reveals that when diffusivity in the tube differs from the rest of the domain, the form of multiplicative noise inherent to spatially varying diffusivity becomes important.
AI.conclusion: The paper resolves long-standing conflicts in narrow escape time estimates through tubes, provides a rigorous asymptotic formula, and demonstrates the significance of multiplicative noise in spatially varying diffusivity, with applications to asymmetric cell division.
